ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Question 12: Depends on your specific interests and whether or not you will be working in the West or with Westerners in your research/ work.

1) The readings for this course were well-curated and extremely interesting. I learned a lot from the readings themselves, and then a lot from class discussions about them. 8) Justin provides great insights on and explanations of foundational frameworks, and is also very skilled at facilitating discussion between students so that we can learn from each other. 10) Justin is awesome. He is thoughtful, insightful, and friendly. This makes him a professor who teaches his students a lot, as well as one who is good at encouraging students to take risks and learn in new ways from new data sources.

The professor was extremely knowledgeable about the material, and passionate as well. He provided a very nuanced perspective on the things we discussed, and did a good job of hearing all of our thoughts.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: This course provided an in-depth look at the history of the American west and how it shaped the region today. I really enjoyed the ability to discuss how current politics are influenced by the historical context of western settlement.
The readings and discussions were very engaging. I learned so much with the reading/ discussion framework of the class. Best course this semester.
Our discussions were really helpful for understanding different facets of the American West.
The class discussions, readings, and professor. It was great how the classes linked together and built on one another.
The readings were incredibly interesting and though-provoking. Discussion was always very engaging as well. The professor's incorporation of films into the syllabus was also very useful.
The course discussions were very productive. I learned from my classmates - they were amazing.

The class discussions were phenomenal. The discussions were led by students who presented the weekly material, and were largely directed by only students. Most students participated strongly each week. Our discussions were allowed to drift to issues the class found most interesting.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Because the classes are discussions formatted by each student, the discussion is mostly based on what they decide. While all of my peers worked very hard this semester, it would have been great to have more input from Justin. Even having one of the topics completely taught by him would have been nice. This way we could get more of his experience and see how he would prefer discussions be led.
I think it's kind of unfair how some people get much easier weekly topics to present upon, both with subject matter and amount of readings.
Honestly, nothing comes to mind.

Perhaps the presentation layout could be re-worked a bit. While helpful, sometimes it seemed like presenters focused on things that weren't the most relevant. Some more direction on what themes to cover would be useful.
The course was mostly student-led discussions. More professor lecturing would be nice.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: NA
N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I wish to live and work in the West post-graduation. Any good researcher must understand and be respectful of the traditions and customs of the places they choose to work. This course taught me about the history and current issues surrounding race, resource management, economy, moral structures and so much more in the West. I feel more equipped to take what I have learned in all my methods classes and apply it to the communities in the West I hope to someday be a part of.
I am interested in working in the West, and this course gave me a great introduction to the West and major themes and issues particular to the region.

I am from the West and so it this course was useful for understanding the historical, environmental, social, and environmental aspects of that region. As someone interested in policy, potentially western policy, this course was very insightful.
This course offers a theoretical component to my otherwise very applied curriculum here. It diversified my learning and reminded me of the human components of environmentalism.
This class is great for anyone planning on working in the West, or for anyone who wants to begin to reflect on how history and social values contribute to environmental issues.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this course in order to learn more about what makes the west a unique region and what its current politics are. Exploring some environmental conflicts and their underlying motivations was informative for how I will think about policy problems in the future,

I chose this course because I felt it would be an interesting and important addition to my curriculum. There are not a lot of courses in which in depth case study and discussion are combined in such a well formatted way at my school. It has better equipped me to live and work in the American West.
To learn more about the factors influencing the west, which I don't think most American history books do justice.

I wasn't sure how relevant this course would be to my professional development, but I had heard good things from students who took it last year and was interested in the topics, so I took it anyway. In the end, this course provided me with new insights and ways of framing issues that I think will stay with me for a long time and directly influence work I do in any field.
I wanted to gain a better understanding of the west as a physical and conceptual landscape.
It met a curriculum requirement. Once in the course, I was very pleasantly surprised by the interesting and relevant material. I'm glad I fit it into my schedule.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, I learned a lot about both the history of the region and how environmental conflicts are playing out currently.
Yes.
Yes, I feel that I learned about a lot of different topics.
My expectations were exceeded. The class was interesting in terms of the topics I learned about and influential in how I will engage with the world in the future.
Yes! I loved discussing the concepts we talked about outside of class time because it was so interesting.
It exceeded my expectations.

Yes, the course greatly exceeded my expectations. I gained a greater understanding of the West, and the stakeholders within it. I also feel more prepared to begin my career in the West working on environmental issues.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take the course -- it's a very interesting perspective on the west, and you will learn a lot that is applicable to other regions as well.
This course is a lot of reading, but it is well worth it. If you have any interest at all in life, work, economics, or environmentalism in the American West this class will not be wasted on you.

Pick a weekly presentation topic with a smaller reading list and try and get it done earlier rather than later in the semester. Start thinking of final projects much earlier than October. Also, do not read for the week more than a couple of days in advance--it's hard to remember specifics if you read too ahead of time.
Take it! Justin is a fantastic professor and you will both enjoy this class and learn a lot from it. It's definitely worth your time.

Make sure to do all the readings because they are very interesting and relevant to discussion. Its best to start thinking about your final projects earlier rather than later, because it gets more difficult to settle upon and execute an idea later in the semester. Take advantage of sharing your ideas with the teaching fellow and professor who are there to help!
Do the readings. Start working on the final project early in the semester.
Take it!
